title: 105_hr4539
content: The "Consular Review Act of 1998" establishes a Board of Visa Appeals under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of State establishes a Board of Visa Appeals composed of 5 members, with no more than 2 being consular officers. The Board has authority to review discretionary decisions of consular officers regarding immigrant and nonimmigrant visas, as well as waiver applications. If the Board finds a decision contrary to the evidence, it can overrule or remand it for further consideration. The Board of Visa Appeals can overrule or remand decisions of consular officers if they are contrary to the evidence. Proceedings before the Board must follow regulations set by the Secretary of State, ensuring notice to all parties involved and access to the written record of the decision. The consular officer must provide the Board with the record of proceeding within 30 days of receiving a request for review. The appellant must be given notice of the Board proceedings and can be represented by counsel at no cost to the Government. A request for review must be made in writing to the Board within 60 days of receiving notice of the denial, revocation, or cancellation. The Board shall review decisions upon request of the alien or interested parties such as petitioners of immigrant or nonimmigrant visa petitions, postsecondary educational institutions, and recognized international agencies. Requests for review must be made in writing within 60 days of notice of denial, revocation, or cancellation. The Board reviews decisions upon request from the alien or interested parties like petitioners of visa petitions, educational institutions, and international agencies. Requests must be made in writing within 60 days of denial, with a limitation of one review every 24 months. The Secretary of State will charge a fee for review requests to cover administration costs. The amendment will take effect 120 days after the enactment of the Act. The amendment made by subsection (a) will take effect 120 days after the enactment of the Act. Proposed regulations must be promulgated within 30 days, and members of the Board of Visa Appeals must be appointed within 120 days. Technical amendments to section 222(f) of the Immigration and Nationality Act are also included. The amendment allows interested parties to inspect the record of proceedings. Section 104(a)(1) is amended to include the provision. The table of contents is updated to reflect the new item.
